AT01.description: Triggered when an application is executed on an endpoint or server. Blocklisted applications are pre-defined in UBA and updated on a regular basis.

detections.description: Checks application launches in Windows Event Log against a predefined list of known bad applications.
detections.name: Blocklisted Application

AT01.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT01.long_description: Triggered when an application is executed on an endpoint or server. Blocklisted applications are pre-defined in UBA and updated on a regular basis.
AT01.name: Blocklisted Application

AT02.description: Triggered off of DNS and/or HTTP data, this anomaly compares domains that are visted against the internal UBA blocklist. If sites match, the anomaly is created.

detections.description: UBA ships with a list of predefined Domains and IPs that are known bad. This will identify when a user visits a URL or IP that has been blocklisted by UBA. Custom domains and IPs can be added.
detections.name: Blocklisted Domain

AT02.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT02.long_description: Triggered off of DNS and/or HTTP data, this anomaly compares domains that are visted against the internal UBA blocklist. If sites match, the anomaly is created.
AT02.name: Blocklisted Domain

AT03.description: Trigerred off of core network traffic, this anomaly compares IP addresses that are visted agains the internal UBA IP Address blocklist. If IPs match, the anomaly is created.

detections.description: UBA ships with a list of predefined Domains and IPs that are known bad. This will identify when a user visits a URL or IP that has been blocklisted by UBA. Custom domains and IPs can be added.
detections.name: Blocklisted IP Address

AT03.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT03.long_description: Trigerred off of core network traffic, this anomaly compares IP addresses that are visted agains the internal UBA IP Address blocklist. If IPs match, the anomaly is created.
AT03.name: Blocklisted IP Address

AT04.description: Triggered off of authentication attempts and/or number of devices a user has access to over time. Identifies possible brute force attacks inside of an environment.

detections.description: Identifies users who have an increasing number of devices accessed over time.
detections.name: Brute Force Attack _Login failures for multiple accounts

detections.description: Identifies possible attempts of brute force by looking at failed and successful login attempts. Failed and successful login attempts are defined by specific event codes from Windows event logs.
detections.name: Password spraying

AT04.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT04.long_description: Triggered off of authentication attempts and/or number of devices a user has access to over time. Identifies possible brute force attacks inside of an environment.
AT04.name: Brute Force Attack

AT05.description: Triggered off of accounting information from firewall data (bytes in/out) to determine an unusually high volume of downloaded data per user from UBA defined internal servers.

detections.description: Detects outliers of downloaded bytes per user from internal servers. This requires internal network traffic to be ingested into UBA.
detections.name: Download from Internal Server

AT05.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT05.long_description: Triggered off of accounting information from firewall data (bytes in/out) to determine an unusually high volume of downloaded data per user from UBA defined internal servers.
AT05.name: Download from Internal Server

AT06.description: Triggered when there is more than expected data transfer for a user or device. This anomaly will often be included in a data exfiltration attempt.

detections.description: This detection looks at a historical baseline of data transfer by device. This type of information typically comes from the accounting information (bytes in/bytes out or packets in/packets out) from either a firewall or proxy. It only looks at connections that behave as file transfers and not other connections (web browsing/video chat).
detections.name: Data uploads to external destination by a device using signal intelligence

detections.description: This detection looks at a historical baseline of data transfer by user. This type of information typically comes from the accounting information (bytes in/bytes out or packets in/packets out) from either a firewall or proxy. It only looks at connections that behave as file transfers and not other connections (web browsing/video chat).
detections.name: Data uploads to external destination by a user using signal intelligence

detections.description: Detects outliers in the outgoing bytes transmission by each user.
detections.name: Excessive amount of data transmission by user

detections.description: Detects outliers in the traffic volume over VPN per user.
detections.name: Excessive data downloaded to workstation while on VPN

detections.description: Detects outliers based on historical baseline by looking at bytes in/out to detect unusual data movement. UBA looks at this data per application.
detections.name: Excessive data transmission by a device using specific application

AT06.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT06.long_description: This is a collection of anomalies that all share data exfiltration as the ultimate goal. This anomaly contains both excessive data transmission from a user and a device perspective, looking at both network and firewall data and connection profiling. The baseline is per user or per device.
AT06.name: Excessive Data Transmission

AT07.description: This is a generic catch all anomaly that can hold alarms generated by 3rd party systems like firewall, IDS/IPS, Enterprise Security, etc.

detections.description: Looks at external alarms from outside systems (IDS, IPS, DLP, etc) and determines the risk of entities in UBA based on those external alarms.
detections.name: Analysis & prioritization of security alerts from other tools

AT07.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT07.long_description: This is a generic catch all anomaly that can hold alarms generated by 3rd party systems like firewall, IDS/IPS, Enterprise Security, etc. Most common use case of this anomaly is bringing in ES Notable Events to add to users' profiles. Additionally, this model classifies these external alarms into categories so that threat models can leverage them against a kill chain phase or MITRE tactic.
AT07.name: External Alarm Activity

AT08.description: This anomaly detects malicious incoming traffic on websites (e.g., SQL injection).

detections.description: Raises anomalies when there are suspicious patterns in incoming web traffic.
detections.name: SQL Injection

AT08.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT08.long_description: This anomaly detects malicious incoming traffic on websites (e.g., SQL injection).
AT08.name: External Website Attack

AT09.description: Trigged when acess to a badge panel (door or otherwise) is denied because the badge is disabled. Disabled doe not neceissarly mean terminated.

detections.description: Detects a door access attempt from a badge that has been disabled
detections.name: Rare badge location by a user

AT09.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT09.long_description: Trigged when acess to a badge panel (door or otherwise) is denied because the badge is disabled. Disabled doe not neceissarly mean terminated.
AT09.name: Failed Access by Disabled Badge

AT10.description: Triggered by multiple failed access attempts at multiple physical locations.

detections.description: Detects multiple failed badge-in attempts with a disabled badge. Disabled badges have been disabled in the badge system. This does not necessarily identify a terminated user.
detections.name: Failed badge attempt from a disabled badge

AT10.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT10.long_description: Similar to "Failed Access by Disabled Badge" - this anomaly detects multiple failed access attempts at multiple physical locations. Disabled badges are set disabled in the badge system. This doesn't not necessarily mean that the user has been terminated.
AT10.name: Failed Badge Accesses on Multiple Doors

AT11.description: Triggered when a user exhibits behavior that indicates that the user may be a flight risk (risk to leave the company).

detections.description: Identifies emails to competitors. Competitors are provided during setup and can be added or deleted at any time in UBA setup.
detections.name: Email to competitor

detections.description: Identifies users who visit job listing sites several times a day. This list is pre-populated and updated with every content update of UBA.
detections.name: User browsing job sites_flight risk user

AT11.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT11.long_description: This anomaly identifies two actions that may be taken by a user. In the first instance, a user sends an email to a competitive entity. These competitors are identified during configuration of UBA. The second case involves browsing pre-defined job sites (e.g., monster, dice, indeed.) This anomaly will trigger when one of or both actions occur.
AT11.name: Flight Risk User

AT12.description: Triggered by users logging into VPN session from multiple locations within a short amount of time.

detections.description: Identifies users who login to VPN from multiple geographical locations in a short amount of time.
detections.name: Landspeed violation/Login from distinct geolocations in short span

AT12.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT12.long_description: Triggered by users logging into VPN session from multiple locations within a short amount of time.
AT12.name: Land Speed Violation

AT13.description: Triggered when an account is created on a workstation or endpoint. This is a local Windows account when the machine is joined to a domain.

detections.description: Identifies any local account creation at the workstation/endpoint level. This requires endpoint data being ingested into UBA.
detections.name: Local account creation

AT13.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT13.long_description: Triggered when an account is created on a workstation or endpoint. This is a local Windows account when the machine is joined to a domain.
AT13.name: Local Account Creation

AT14.description: Triggered by devices that have recurring machine generated traffic. Looking at both web and network traffic.

detections.description: Identifies suspicious beaconing activity by looking at network traffic for systematic or repeating traffic.
detections.name: Machine Generated Beacon

AT14.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT14.long_description: Triggered by devices that have recurring machine generated traffic. Looking at both web and network traffic.
AT14.name: Machine Generated Beacon

AT15.category: Zero Trust|Lateral Movement|Insider Threat|Account Compromise|IAM Analytics
AT15.description: This anomaly contains multiple detection methods that look at Windows Event Logs for malicious activity (e.g., clearning audit logs). Check associated detection methods for an exhastive list of what triggers this anomaly.

detections.description: Any activity by an inactive user. An inactive user in UBA is any user that is marked "InActive" in the HR data ingestion process. User status could be different from account status, if the user has multiple accounts.
detections.name: Activity by terminated user

detections.description: Identifies actions in Active Directory where an user performs an administrative change on his own account.
detections.name: Administrative changes on one's own account

detections.description: identifies use of audit log clearing in a Windows environment. This detection method looks for event code 1102.
detections.name: Clearing audit logs

detections.description: Detects possible golden ticket attacks by identifying events in Windows Security Logs.
detections.name: Golden ticket detection

detections.description: Identifies accounts where operations are performed upon itself (e.g., Self elevation).
detections.name: Operations to self

detections.description: Detects any usage of the KRBTGT account ( https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/janelewis/2006/12/19/the-krbtgt-account-what-is-it/ )
detections.name: Usage of recovery account

AT15.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT15.long_description: This anomaly contains multiple detection methods that look at Windows Event Logs for malicious activity (e.g., clearning audit logs). Check associated detection methods for an exhastive list of what triggers this anomaly.
AT15.name: Malicious AD Activity

AT16.category: Zero Trust|Lateral Movement|Insider Threat|Account Compromise|IAM Analytics
AT16.description: Triggered when a user fails authentication multiple times. This anomaly is only  triggered when the number of authentication failures exceeds the enterprise average.

detections.description: Detects an abnormally high volume of authentication failures for a user. This is based on enterprise average.
detections.name: High volume of authentication failures for a given user

AT16.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT16.long_description: Triggered when a user fails authentication multiple times. This anomaly is only  triggered when the number of authentication failures exceeds the enterprise average.
AT16.name: Multiple Authentication Failures

AT17.category: Zero Trust|Lateral Movement|Insider Threat|Account Compromise|IAM Analytics
AT17.description: Triggered on outliers of number of successes and failures per user authenticating against services or machines.

detections.description: Outlier detection of login failures per user.
detections.name: High volume of login failures for a given user

AT17.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT17.long_description: Triggered on outliers of number of successes and failures per user authenticating against services or machines.
AT17.name: Multiple Authentications

AT18.description: Triggered by number of badge accesses per user per day based on historical baseline.

detections.description: Detects an abnormally high number of attempts to use a badge for a user. This is based on enterprise average.
detections.name: High volume of badge attempts for a given user

AT18.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT18.long_description: Triggered by number of badge accesses per user per day based on historical baseline.
AT18.name: Multiple Badge Accesses

AT19.description: Triggered by multiple login errors against Box authentication. This is for failed logins only. Similar to the "Multiple Box Logins" anomaly.

detections.description: Outlier detection of box failed logins per user.
detections.name: High volume of login errors on box for a given user

AT19.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT19.long_description: Triggered by multiple login errors against Box authentication. This is for failed logins only. Similar to the "Multiple Box Logins" anomaly.
AT19.name: Multiple Box login errors

AT20.description: Triggered by the total number of  Box logins per user per day based on historical baseline. These are successful logins only.

detections.description: Outlier detection of box logins per user.
detections.name: High volume of logins on box for a given user

AT20.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT20.long_description: Triggered by the total number of  Box logins per user per day based on historical baseline. These are successful logins only.
AT20.name: Multiple Box logins

AT21.description: Triggered by a high volume of box operations by user. The number of operations  is compared to the enterprise average.

detections.description: Detects an abnormally high number of box operations for a user. This is based on enterprise average.
detections.name: High volume of box operations for a given user

AT21.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT21.long_description: Triggered by a high volume of box operations by user. The number of operations  is compared to the enterprise average.
AT21.name: Multiple Box operations

AT22.description: Triggered when the number of external alarms from external tools (IDS, IPS, DLP) is higher for a specific user when compared to the enterprise average.

detections.description: Detects an abnormally high number of events from an external security tool for a device. This is based on enterprise average.
detections.name: High volume of alerts from other security tools on a given device

AT22.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT22.long_description: Triggered when the number of external alarms from external tools (IDS, IPS, DLP) is higher for a specific user when compared to the enterprise average.
AT22.name: Multiple External Alarms

AT23.description: Triggered when multiple users fail to badge in at a single badge-in access point. This could be used to detect both a physical brute force attack or faulty hardware.

detections.description: Detects multiple failures by multiple users at a single badge-in station. This could be used to detect faulty hardware of the badge detector or a physical brute force attack.
detections.name: Failed badge attempts from multiple users at same door

AT23.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT23.long_description: Triggered when multiple users fail to badge in at a single badge-in access point. This could be used to detect both a physical brute force attack or faulty hardware.
AT23.name: Multiple Failed Badge Access Attempts

AT24.category: Zero Trust|Lateral Movement|Insider Threat|Account Compromise|IAM Analytics
AT24.description: Triggered when the number of successful logins by a user is higher than the enterprise average. This anomaly could point to a number of things, including lateral movement, account takeover, or just general suspicious behavior.

detections.description: Outlier detection of logins per user.
detections.name: High volume of logins for a given user

AT24.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT24.long_description: Triggered when the number of successful logins by a user is higher than the enterprise average. This anomaly could point to a number of things, including lateral movement, account takeover, or just general suspicious behavior.
AT24.name: Multiple Logins

AT25.description: Triggered when there is more than expected traffic destined for a single device. Most typically this anomaly is seen with DDOS behavior or something similar.

detections.description: Detects a DDOS attempt by identifying unwanted traffic destined for a host.
detections.name: DDOS amplification

AT25.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT25.long_description: Triggered when there is more than expected traffic destined for a single device. Most typically this anomaly is seen with DDOS behavior or something similar.
AT25.name: Network Protocol Violation

AT26.category: Zero Trust|Lateral Movement|Insider Threat|Account Compromise|IAM Analytics
AT26.description: Triggered when Windows events occur outside of the normal baseline for a user.

detections.description: Correlates the rate of behavioral changes in Active Directory actions for each account. The correlation happens with: (a) each account's historic profile, and (b) with the activity of other accounts in the enterprise.
detections.name: Unusual Windows Security Event Sequences

AT26.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT26.long_description: Triggered when a sequence of events within the Windows Security Event log is outside of the norm. Normal behavior is baselined from the users' past behavior but also from the enterprise. (e.g., 98% of the time after login, users open Outlook. It would be unusual then, for a user to login, create a new user, elevate that user to admin, etc.)
AT26.name: Period with Unusual Windows Security Event Sequences

AT27.description: Triggered by external email monitoring tools when a specific user or group is a possible target of a spear phishing campaign.

detections.description: Uses external notifications from an existing email monitoring tool to identify incoming spear phishing email that has been targeting a specific department in the organization.
detections.name: Spear phishing

AT27.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT27.long_description: Triggered by external email monitoring tools when a specific user or group is a possible target of a spear phishing campaign.
AT27.name: Possible Phishing Attempt

AT28.description: Triggered when an internal webserver is accessed from an outside source.

detections.description: Detects external access to internal web servers as possible webshell activity.
detections.name: Potential webshell activity

AT28.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT28.long_description: Triggered when an internal webserver is accessed from an outside source.
AT28.name: Potential Webshell Activity

AT29.description: Triggers when a device exhibits either horizontal/vertical scanning patterns or appears to be sending data to a large number of ports per destination device.

detections.description: Identifies devices that exhibit suspicious vertical/horizontal scanning patterns.
detections.name: Host Scan

detections.description: Identifies devices correlated to suspicious vertical and horizontal scanning patterns.
detections.name: Service/Port Scan

AT29.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT29.long_description: Triggers when a device exhibits either horizontal/vertical scanning patterns or appears to be sending data to a large number of ports per destination device.
AT29.name: Scanning Activity

AT30.description: This anomaly contains multiple detection methods that look at account events for suspcious activity (e.g., activity by an expired user). Check the associated detection methods for an exhaustive list of what triggers this anomaly.

detections.description: Detects any account that has been created or deleted in the past 24 hour time period. This detection method looks at both local and domain accounts.
detections.name: Account created and deleted in a short span

detections.description: Identifies users who email to themselves outside of the organization. This uses logic based on collected HR data to determine if a user internally is the same as an external email. Example, John Smith to jsmith@gmail.com would create an anomaly. John Smith to bjones@gmail.com would not.
detections.name: Email to self

detections.description: Identifies successful/unsuccessful interactive logins by service accounts. Service accounts are identified during HR data ingestion into UBA.
detections.name: Interactive logins by service accounts

detections.description: Identifies accounts that have tried to login, but were rejected by the domain controller because the account is disabled in AD.
detections.name: Login attempts from disabled account

detections.description: Detects when a user is added and removed from a group in the same day.
detections.name: Member added and removed from a security enabled group in a short span

detections.description: Detects when any new accounts are created. This looks at both domain and local accounts.
detections.name: New account created

detections.description: Performs peer group analysis of Unusual AD Event codes and then identifies if there are any event codes that have been triggered by a person and not by any other members in the peer group.
detections.name: Peer group outlier of Windows security event

detections.description: Detects activity from a terminated user. Terminated users are users who are marked inactive/disabled in the HR data ingest process.
detections.name: Terminated user activity

detections.description: Identifies VPN traffic by a service account. Service accounts are identified in HR data ingest in UBA.
detections.name: VPN login using service account

AT30.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT30.long_description: This anomaly contains multiple detection methods that look at account events for suspcious activity (e.g., activity by an expired user). Check the associated detection methods for an exhaustive list of what triggers this anomaly.
AT30.name: Suspicious Account Activity

AT31.category: Zero Trust|Lateral Movement|Insider Threat|Account Compromise|IAM Analytics
AT31.description: Triggered when an account lockout occurs without any corresponding cause (e.g., password change, password reset, etc.)

detections.description: Looks for suspicious account lockouts that do not have any associations with password changes, password resets, password expiry within a specific time interval in and around the lockout period.
detections.name: Suspicious account lockouts

AT31.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT31.long_description: Triggered when an account lockout occurs without any corresponding cause (e.g., password change, password reset, etc.)
AT31.name: Suspicious Account Lockout

AT32.description: This anomaly contains a number of detection methods surrounding box usage and malicious intent (e.g., file relay through box). Check the associated detection methods for a comprehensive list of what triggers this anomaly.

detections.description: Looks for a specific set of Box commands that indicates data collection.
detections.name: Data collection from box

detections.description: Detects external alarms (e.g., by firewalls) that have unusual characteristics.
detections.name: Rare alert signature for a given user

detections.description: Identifies users uploading data from one location and then downloading the same data from a new, different location.
detections.name: File relay on multiple devices using box

detections.description: Identifies users whose number of collaboration acceptances is outside the normal baseline.
detections.name: High number of collaboration accepts on box

detections.description: Looks for specific set of box commands that indicate a malicious publication with the intent of leaking the data
detections.name: Malicious publication - Data leakage through box

detections.description: Detects upload policy violation in box.
detections.name: Data theft - Policy violation

detections.description: Looks for specific set of box commands that indicate a malicious publication with the intent of publishing a malicious file or exploit
detections.name: Malicious publication - watering hole attack

AT32.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT32.long_description: This anomaly contains a number of detection methods surrounding box usage and malicious intent (e.g., file relay through box). Check the associated detection methods for a comprehensive list of what triggers this anomaly.
AT32.name: Suspicious Box Usage

AT33.description: This anomaly contains multiple detection methods surrounding suspicious data movement (e.g., sending email to self, external DLP alarms, etc.)

detections.description: Identifies external DLP events where a file includes both social security numbers and a credit card in the same file. This file must trigger the external DLP system's policy.
detections.name: DLP alarms detecting SSN & CC together in same file

detections.description: Identifies external DLP events where a file's name is changed while copying. This requires external DLP functionality.
detections.name: DLP alarm representing a change of name while copying

detections.description: Identifies external DLP alarms (from DLP system) that show users printing documents that violate multiple DLP policies. An external DLP system must be in place for this anomaly to fire.
detections.name: File print violating multiple DLP policies

detections.description: Identifies users sending emails to external domains that contains a resume as one of the attachments.
detections.name: Resume sent externally

detections.description: Detects attempt of transferring a file across multiple channels(USB,CD/DVD,HTTP,Email,Print etc.).
detections.name: Same file being attempted to transfer across multiple egress channels

detections.description: Detects sensitive data being sent and/or posted to personal email accounts or personal file sharing sites. This uses logic based on collected HR data to determine if a user internally is the same as an external email. Example, John Smith to jsmith@gmail.com would create an anomaly. John Smith to bjones@gmail.com would not.
detections.name: Sensitive data_violating DLP policies transfer to personal sites/mail

detections.description: Detected suspicious file transfer or shell communication from user to an external domain / IP address. The suspiciousness is determined by the URL categorization of the destination.
detections.name: Suspicious file transfer or SSH connections to external domains / IP addresses

detections.description: Identifies a user who transferred multiple files out of organization triggering DLP alarms. An external DLP system must be in place for this detection method to work.
detections.name: User triggering DLP alarms across multiple files

detections.description: Identifies users who tried to copy data out of organization across multiple channels triggering DLP alerts. An external DLP system must be in place for this detection method to work.
detections.name: user triggering multiple types of DLP alarms

detections.description: Detects outliers in the traffic volume over VPN per user per destination zone
detections.name: Excessive data transmission outbound going through a different destinationZone

detections.description: Detects outliers based on historical baseline by looking at bytes in/out to detect unusual data movement. UBA looks at this data per application.
detections.name: Excessive data transmission by a device using specific application

detections.description: Analyzes different types of data transfers per account, both LAN and WAN, to identify unusual data movements using various countries.
detections.name: User transmitting excessive data for a application

detections.description: Analyzes different types of data transfers per account, both LAN and WAN, to identify unusual data movements to different countries.
detections.name: User transmitting excessive data for a country

detections.description: This detection method looks at DLP alarms and access of the file(s) in question. If the user or user peer group has never accessed that file, an anomaly is raised.
detections.name: Data transmission attempt of a sensitive document_violated DLP policies that was never accessed by the user or by the members in the same department

detections.description: Identifies users who send a higher volume of data via email. This is based on individual users.
detections.name: High volume of data sent over email

detections.description: Detects deviation in number of DLP matches across DLP alarms raised by a user. This detection identifies the average number of DLP matches on any given day in the past and verifies if the current day significantly exceeds the prior baseline.
detections.name: Spike in DLP matches

detections.description: Detects deviation in number of prints across DLP alarms raised by a user. This detection identifies the average number of prints on any given day in the past and verifies if the current day significantly exceeds the prior baseline.
detections.name: Spike in DLP prints

detections.description: Detects deviation in number of DLP alerts for a given user where the user has transferred files. This detection identifies the average number of DLP alarms on any given day in the past and verifies if the current day significantly exceeds the prior baseline. This detection does not cover any HTTP based DLP alerts.
detections.name: Spike in number of DLP alerts where file_s has been transferred out of the organization

detections.description: Performs peer group analysis on DLP data to identify anomalous users. This is used to detect a data transmission attempt that violated DLP policies on a channel that was never been used by the members in the same peer group. Requires external DLP information.
detections.name: Usage of data transmission channel that was never used by the members in the same department

detections.description: Identifies upload/transfer of data to external file sharing sites. This categorization is provided by proxy or NGFW logs.
detections.name: Data transfer/upload to storage sites

AT33.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT33.long_description: This anomaly contains multiple detection methods surrounding suspicious data movement (e.g., sending email to self, external DLP alarms, etc.) Check the associated detection methods for a comprehensive list of possible triggers for this anomaly.
AT33.name: Suspicious Data Movement

AT34.description: Triggered when a user visits a malicious or suspicious site. This classification is determined by NGFW categories.

detections.description: Identifies users who visit a malicious URI. This categorization comes from proxy or NGFW categorization.
detections.name: User visiting malicious URI

detections.description: Identifies users who visit suspicious URI such as adult/spyware/adware sites. This categorization comes from proxy or NGFW categorization.
detections.name: Users visiting suspicious URI

detections.description: Identifies users who visited malicious URI based on the categorization from next gen firewalls that have that classification.
detections.name: Suspicious Domain Communication

AT34.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT34.long_description: Triggered when a user visits a malicious or suspicious site. This classification is determined by NGFW categories.
AT34.name: Suspicious Domain Communication

AT35.description: Triggered when a user visits a suspicious domain name that appears to be algorithmically generated.

detections.description: Detects covert and malicious communication patterns in network traffic.
detections.name: Suspicious Domain Name/Algorithmically generated domain

AT35.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT35.long_description: Triggered when a user visits a suspicious domain name that appears to be algorithmically generated.
AT35.name: Suspicious Domain Name

AT36.description: Triggered by detecting sequences in HTTP requests that signify a possible exploit.

detections.description: Detects sequences of HTTP requests within a short period of time that suggests infection has taken place.
detections.name: Potential Exploit Chain

AT36.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
AT36.long_description: Triggered by detecting sequences in HTTP requests that signify a possible exploit.
AT36.name: Suspicious HTTP Redirects

AT37.description: This anomaly contains multiple detections that inspect network traffic and look for suspicious activity (e.g., DNS data exfiltration). Check the associated detection methods for a comprehensive list of possible triggers for this anomaly.

detections.description: Identifies possible DNS exfiltration by inspecting firewall traffic.
detections.name: DNS Data Transfer

detections.description: Looks at network traffic to determine if DNS is used to transfer data.
detections.name: TCP DNS Data Transfer

detections.description: Detects attempted data exfiltration through NTP by examining firewall traffic.
detections.name: NTP Data Transfer

detections.description: Determines SCP/SFTP type traffic from internal hosts to an external host.
detections.name: Secure Copy to External Host

detections.description: Determines SCP/SFTP type traffic from external hosts to an internal host.

TT01.description: This threat is generated when an account (or multiple accounts) exhibit behavior outside of the normal baseline that indicates a compromise.
TT01.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT01.long_description: This threat is generated when an account (or multiple accounts) exhibit behavior outside of the normal baseline that indicates a compromise. It further differentiates itself by including suspicious internal activity associated with that account. Indicators of compromise could be something as simple as number of logins per day or as complex as lateral movement or beaconing. An example of suspicious internal activity is data movement from one internal resource to another, or RDP hopping. This threat contains a number of possible anomalies.
TT01.name: Account Compromise with Suspicious Internal Activity

TT02.description: This threat is generated when an account or multiple accounts exhibit behavior outside of the normal baseline that indicates a compromise.
TT02.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT02.long_description: This threat is generated when an account  or multiple accounts exhibit behavior outside of the normal baseline that indicates a compromise. It further includes data exfiltration activity associated with that account. Indicators of compromise could be something as simple as number of logins per day or as complex as lateral movement or beaconing. An example of data exfiltration is data movement from an internal server to an external server, or emailing to self. This threat contains a number of possible anomalies.
TT02.name: Account Compromised followed by Exfiltration

TT03.description: This threat is generated when a single account or multiple accounts have repeated login failures followed by malicious activity such as data movement or scanning activity.
TT03.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT03.long_description: This threat is generated when a single account or multiple accounts have repeated login failures followed by malicious activity such as data movement or scanning activity. Please see the associated anomalies to see what malicious activity the threat is looking for.
TT03.name: Brute Force

TT04.description: This is a threat that looks for login anomalies such as a land speed violation followed by malicious activity like unusual machine access or unusual access time.
TT04.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT04.long_description: This is a threat that looks for login anomalies such as a land speed violation followed by malicious activity like unusual machine access or unusual access time. Please see the associated anomalies to see what malicious activity the threat is looking for.
TT04.name: Compromised Account

TT05.description: This is a threat rule that looks for potential webshell or external traffic followed up by data movement or unusual data access. Please see the associated anomalies to see what malicious data movement the threat rule is looking for.
TT05.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT05.long_description: This is a threat rule that looks for potential webshell or external traffic followed up by data movement or unusual data access. Please see the associated anomalies to see what malicious data movement the threat rule is looking for.
TT05.name: Compromised Web Server

TT06.description: This threat is created by data exfiltration by excessive data transmissions by a device or user in a traditional network setting or via VPN.
TT06.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT06.long_description: This threat is created by data exfiltration by excessive data transmissions by a device or user in a traditional network setting or via VPN. Note: There are other exfiltration threats that contain other behavior, this is just the activity of data exfiltration. This may be seen in tandem with other threats that have been created by UBA.
TT06.name: Exfiltration

TT07.description: This threat is based on the compromised account threat, however looks for data exfiltration after account takeover instead of suspicious behavior.
TT07.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT07.long_description: This threat is based on the compromised account threat, however looks for data exfiltration after account takeover instead of suspicious behavior. This threat has a higher confidence than "Data Exfiltration after Account Takeover, Medium" due to the limited anomaly set that UBA looks at. Please see the associated anomalies to see what account takeover and data exfiltration behaviors UBA is scanning for.
TT07.name: Data Exfiltration after Account Takeover, High

TT08.description: This threat is based on the compromised account threat, however looks for data exfiltration after account takeover instead of suspicious behavior.
TT08.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT08.long_description: This threat is based on the compromised account threat, however looks for data exfiltration after account takeover instead of suspicious behavior. This threat has a lower confidence than "Data Exfiltration after Account Takeover, High" due to the expanded anomaly set that UBA looks at. Please see the associated anomalies to see what account takeover and data exfiltration behaviors UBA is scanning for.
TT08.name: Data Exfiltration after Account Takeover, Medium

TT09.description: This threat combines staging data and data exfiltration.
TT09.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT09.long_description: This threat combines staging data and data exfiltration. Data staging includes copying or moving data from one location to another, often times cloud file systems or through email. Once the data is staged the malicious user then uses different methods to exfiltrate the data. This again can be through email or suspicious data movement.
TT09.name: Data Exfiltration after Data Staging

TT10.description: This threat is generated when an account or device exhibits behavior outside of the normal baseline. It further includes data exfiltration activity associated with that account.
TT10.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT10.long_description: This threat is generated when an account or device exhibits behavior outside of the normal baseline. It further includes data exfiltration actiivity associated with that account. Indicators of suspicious activity could be something as simple as number of logins per day or unusual Wiindows event logs attributed to that account or device. An example of data exfiltration is data movement from an internal server to an external server, or emaiiling to self. This threat contains a number of possible anomalies.
TT10.name: Data Exfiltration by suspicious user or device

TT11.description: This threat is generated when an account (or multiple accounts) exhibit behavior outside of the normal baseline that indicates a compromise. It further differentiates itself by including data exfiltration associated with that account.
TT11.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT11.long_description: This threat is generated when an account (or multiple accounts) exhibit behavior outside of the normal baseline that indicates a compromise. It further differentiates itself by including data exfiltration associated with that account. Indicators of compromise could be something as simple as number of logins per day or as complex as lateral movement or beaconing. An example of data exfiltration is data movement from an internal server to an external server, or emaiiling to self. This threat contains a number of possible anomalies.
TT11.name: Exfiltration after Account Compromise

TT12.description: This threat is generated when a device exhibits behavior outside of the normal baseline that indicates a compromise. It further differentiates itself by including data exfiltration associated with that device.
TT12.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT12.long_description: This threat is generated when a device exhibits behavior outside of the normal baseline that indicates a compromise. It further differentiates itself by including data exfiltration associated with that device. Indicators of infection could be something as simple as data movement or as complex as visiting multiple malicious URIs or beaconing. An example of data exfiltration is data movement from an internal server to an external server, or DNS data transfers. This threat contains a number of possible anomalies.
TT12.name: Exfiltration after Infection

TT13.description: This threat is generated when an account (or multiple accounts) exhibit behavior outside of the normal baseline. It further differentiates itself by including data exfiltration associated with that account.
TT13.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT13.long_description: This threat is generated when an account (or multiple accounts) exhibit behavior outside of the normal baseline. It further differentiates itself by including data exfiltration associated with that account. Indicators of suspicious activity could be something as simple as number of logins per day or as complex as multiple event codes never seen before. An example of data exfiltration is data movement from one internal resource to an external or DNS data transfer. This threat contains a number of possible anomalies.
TT13.name: Exfiltration after Suspicious Internal Activity

TT14.description: This threat looks for a suspicious first step such as a suspicious powershell command or USB insertion.
TT14.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT14.long_description: This threat looks for a suspicious first step such as a suspicious powershell command or USB insertion. It then goes on to detect any suspicious network activity or processes that are performing actions on the host, such as local account creation or malicious AD activity. The threat is created from a device perspective, although any users who have utilized that device will be associated with the threat. This is often coupled with one of the malware focused threats.
TT14.name: Infected Host

TT15.description: This threat is generated when a device exhibits behavior outside of the normal baseline that indicates a compromise.
TT15.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT15.long_description: This threat is generated when a device exhibits behavior outside of the normal baseline that indicates a compromise. It further differentiates itself by including data exfiltration associated with that device. Indicators of infection could be something as simple as data movement or as complex as visiting multiple malicious URIs or beaconing. An example of data exfiltration is data movement from an internal server to an external server, or DNS data transfers. This threat contains a number of possible anomalies.
TT15.name: Infection followed by Exfiltration

TT16.description: This threat is generated when UBA detects activity from a user (or users) that looks like possible lateral movement in the network.
TT16.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT16.long_description: This threat is generated when UBA detects activity from a user (or users) that looks like possible lateral movement in the network. Examples of activity that may be included in this threat are: multiple logins, unusual machine access, network exploration, and unusual login times.
TT16.name: Lateral Movement

TT17.description: This threat looks detects network communication to malicious domains followed by suspicious activity by the device or user.
TT17.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT17.long_description: This threat looks detects network communication to malicious domains followed by suspicious activity by the device or user. Suspicious activity in this instance can be anything from data movement and staging to network exploration or unusual machine access. This threat is often see with other malware focused threats.
TT17.name: Malicious URI with Potential Malware

TT18.description: This threat is generated when a device exhibits behavior that could be attributed to malware. Examples of indicators of malware are beaconing, suspicous data movement, and unusual VPN access.
TT18.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT18.long_description: This threat is generated when a device exhibits behavior that could be attributed to malware. Examples of indicators of malware are beaconing, suspicous data movement, and unusual VPN access.
TT18.name: Malware

TT19.description: This threat is a simple rule to look for unusual badge access time as well as multiple failed badge accesses. UBA has the ability to create simple correlation threat rules based on anomalies. This threat is one such rule.
TT19.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT19.long_description: This threat is a simple rule to look for unusual badge access time as well as multiple failed badge accesses. UBA has the ability to create simple correlation threat rules based on anomalies. This threat is one such rule.
TT19.name: Multiple failed badge attempts and unusual badge access time

TT20.description: This threat brings to light users who are possible flight risks.
TT20.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT20.long_description: This threat brings to light users who are possible flight risks. However, in addition to being a flight risk, this user has also performed actions that signal that it may be possible he will exfiltrate data. Actions that lead to exfiltration of data in this instance are events such as: suspicious data movement, upload of information to a cloud file system, or a DLP external alarm.
TT20.name: Potential Flight Risk Exfiltration

TT21.description: This threat is generated when a potential flight risk user has staged data but not yet exfiltrated it.
TT21.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT21.long_description: This threat is generated when a potential flight risk user has staged data but not yet exfiltrated it. Data staging includes copying a large amount of data or downloading large volumes of data. This is different than "Potential Flight Risk Exfiltration" due to the collection of data rather than the exfiltration of it.
TT21.name: Potential Flight Risk Staging

TT22.description: This threat is generated when UBA detects a potential phishing attempt (email inbound or spear phishing) followed up by suspicious activity from the user or device.
TT22.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT22.long_description: This threat is generated when UBA detects a potential phishing attempt (email inbound or spear phishing) followed up by suspicious activity from the user or device. Suspicious activity in this instance may include visiting a blocklisted website or machine beaconing.
TT22.name: Potential Phishing Attack

TT23.description: This threat is a simple rule to look for privilege escalation occurring after a suspicious powershell command. UBA has the ability to create simple correlation threat rules based on anomalies. This threat is one such rule.
TT23.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT23.long_description: This threat is a simple rule to look for privilege escalation occurring after a suspicious powershell command. UBA has the ability to create simple correlation threat rules based on anomalies. This threat is one such rule.
TT23.name: Privilege Escalation after Powershell Activity

TT24.description: This threat is generated when a publicly facing website is possibly under attack. Typical indicators in this threat are things like SQL injection.
TT24.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT24.long_description: This threat is generated when a publicly facing website is possibly under attack. Typical indicators in this threat are things like SQL injection.
TT24.name: Public facing Website Attack

TT25.description: This threat is generated when a user (or group of users) exhibit behavior that indicates their account has been compromised or taken over by a remote adversary.
TT25.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT25.long_description: This threat is generated when a user (or group of users) exhibit behavior that indicates their account has been compromised or taken over by a remote adversary. This is different than the normal compromised account threat in that it also exhibits activity that indicates malicious intent, outgoing connections, and internal expansion.
TT25.name: Remote Account Takeover

TT26.description: Threat is generated when a user or device exhibits suspicious behavior after an intrusion.
TT26.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT26.long_description: This threat is generated when a user or device exhibits suspicious behavior after an intrusion. Intrusions occur when there is any unauthorized network access by a program, device, or user. This could be anything from a simple malware outbreak to a full on attack. This threat will display the suspicious activity that occurs after that intrusion and will most likely be associated with another threat detailing the intrusion (e.g., malware, account compromise).
TT26.name: Suspicious Activity After Intrusion

TT27.description: This threat is generated when a user (or a group of users) exhibit suspicious behavior involving badge systems.
TT27.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT27.long_description: This threat is generated when a user (or a group of users) exhibit suspicious behavior involving badge systems.
TT27.name: Suspicious Badge Activity

TT28.category: Adversary Tactics|Endpoint Compromise|Malware|IAM Analytics|Account Compromise|Lateral Movement
TT28.description: This threat is generated when a user (or group of users) exhibit general suspicious behavior, specifically patterns of behavior that are outside the normal baseline for the user.
TT28.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT28.long_description: This threat is generated when a user (or group of users) exhibit general suspicious behavior, specifically patterns of behavior that are outside the normal baseline for the user. This threat is a general threat that may accompany other threats.
TT28.name: Suspicious Behavior

TT29.description: This threat is generated when a user (or group of users) exhibit behavior that indicates the user is involved in data collection.
TT29.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT29.long_description: This threat is generated when a user (or group of users) exhibit behavior that indicates the user is involved in data collection. This data collection needs to be outside the normal baseline of that user. This activity could include: unusual machine access, data staging, data download or upload to cloud, or even USB injections and copy actions. This threat may be included with other data exfiltration threats or account compromise threats.
TT29.name: Suspicious Data Collection

TT30.description: This threat is generated when a suspicious domain or IP address is visited by a user; after which that user or device starts to display "malware like" activity.
TT30.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT30.long_description: This threat is generated when a suspicious domain or IP address is visited by a user; after which that user or device starts to display "malware-like" activity. Malware activity could be anything from beaconing to continuous URI visits. This threat will most likely be accompanied by other malware threats.
TT30.name: Suspicious Domain Communication followed by Malware Activity

TT31.category: Adversary Tactics|Endpoint Compromise|Malware|IAM Analytics|Account Compromise|Lateral Movement
TT31.description: This threat is a catch all threat that contains external alarms from third party tools (e.g., IDS, IPS, DLP).
TT31.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT31.long_description: This threat is a catch all threat that contains external alarms from third party tools (e.g., IDS, IPS, DLP).
TT31.name: Suspicious External Alarm Activity

TT32.description: This threat is generated when there is suspicious malware activity following strange HTTP redirects.
TT32.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT32.long_description: This threat is generated when there is suspicious malware activity following strange HTTP redirects. Suspicious malware activity may include: data movement, unusual machine access, or blocklisted applications launching. This threat will most likely be accompanied by other malware threats.
TT32.name: Suspicious HTTP Redirects followed by Suspected Infection

TT33.description: This threat is generated when there is suspicious malware activity following a blocklisted or malicious domain visit.
TT33.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT33.long_description: This threat is generated when there is suspicious malware activity following a blocklisted or malicious domain visit. Suspicious malware activity may include: data movement, unusual machine access, or blocklisted applications launching. This threat will most likely be accompanied by other malware threats.
TT33.name: Suspicious URL Communications and Redirects

TT34.description: This threat is generated when there is suspicious activity surrounding a public cloud file share followed by malware activity.
TT34.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT34.long_description: This threat is generated when there is suspicious activity surrounding a public cloud file share followed by malware activity. Suspicious malware activity may include: data movement, unusual machine access, or blocklisted applications launching. This threat will most likely be accompanied by other malware threats.
TT34.name: Watering Hole Infection

TT35.description: This threat is generated when an internal website is accessed from outside the network.
TT35.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
TT35.long_description: This threat is generated when an internal website is accessed from outside the network.
TT35.name: Web Site Compromised (Webshell)

blocklisted_application.description: Raises anomalies when the input data matches a set of predefined patterns in Microsoft Windows logs.
blocklisted_application.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
blocklisted_application.name: Blocklisted Application

blocklisted_domain.description: Generates anomalies for traffic that goes to Blocklisted Domains.
blocklisted_domain.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
blocklisted_domain.name: Blocklisted Domain

blocklisted_ip_address.description: Generates anomalies for traffic that goes to Blocklisted IPs
blocklisted_ip_address.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
blocklisted_ip_address.name: Blocklisted IP Address

detection_uba_email_anomaly.description: This detection looks for emails that are suspicious because of their sender, domain rareness, or behavior differences. This is an anomaly generated by Splunk User Behavior Analytics (UBA).
detection_uba_email_anomaly.help: This detection monitors for emails that are suspicious because of their sender, domain rareness, or behavior differences, as determined by Splunk UBA. In this search, we query the "UEBA" data model to look for anomalies that are raised by the "SuspiciousEmailDetectionModel" and will output the count, description of the anomaly, signature, the type of event in UBA, the severity, and the user who received a potentially suspicious email from a newly seen domain. It will also output all the categories associated with that anomaly.
detection_uba_email_anomaly.name: Suspicious Email - UBA Anomaly

download_from_internal_server.description: Detects outliers in the timeseries of downloaded bytes from possible internal servers per user.
download_from_internal_server.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
download_from_internal_server.name: Download from Internal Server

excessive_data_transmission.description: Detects outliers in the timeseries of outgoing bytes transmission by each user, and each device. This detection will occur both normal traffic, VPN traffic, and separately after profiling connections. The profiling connections model only considers connections that behave as file transfers and ignores other type of connections, such as regular web browsing and interactive chat/video connections. Connection profiling aims to reduce False Positives (FP). Note that connection profiling is only available when network events include information about number of packets.
excessive_data_transmission.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
excessive_data_transmission.name: Excessive Data Transmission

external_alarm_activity.deprecated_not_used_anymore_datasource: DLP|IDS or IPS|Host-based IDS|Anti-Virus|Web Application Firewall
external_alarm_activity.description: Computes risk analytics for the external alarm of entities and raises anomalies for the most noteworthy external alarm activity.
external_alarm_activity.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
external_alarm_activity.mitre_notes: This is too generic to map to a specific technique.  The alarms could be from various systems
external_alarm_activity.name: External Alarm Activity

external_website_attack.description: Raises anomalies when there are suspicious patterns in incoming web traffic.
external_website_attack.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
external_website_attack.name: External Website Attack

flight_risk_user.description: Detecting indications of a persistent interest in flight risk based on signals in email, web, and other user activity.
flight_risk_user.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
flight_risk_user.name: Flight Risk User

land_speed_violation.description: Raises anomalies when accounts login over VPN from multiple locations within a short time.
land_speed_violation.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
land_speed_violation.name: Land Speed Violation
land_speed_violation.searchKeywords: login log in logon log on sign

machine_generated_beacon.description: Correlates beaconing activity with global information in the enterprise to identify suspicious beaconing activity.
machine_generated_beacon.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
machine_generated_beacon.name: Machine Generated Beacon

malicious_ad_activity.description: Raises anomalies when the input data matches a set of predefined patterns in Microsoft Windows logs.
malicious_ad_activity.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
malicious_ad_activity.name: Malicious AD Activity

multiple_authentication_failures.description: Detects outliers in the timeseries of service or machine authentication failures per user.
multiple_authentication_failures.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
multiple_authentication_failures.name: Multiple Authentication Failures

multiple_authentications.description: Detects outliers in the timeseries of service or machine authentication successes per user.
multiple_authentications.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
multiple_authentications.name: Multiple Authentications

multiple_box_login_errors.description: Detects outliers in the timeseries of Box login failures per Box user.
multiple_box_login_errors.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
multiple_box_login_errors.name: Multiple Box Login Errors
multiple_box_login_errors.searchKeywords: dropbox google drive login log in logon log on sign

multiple_box_logins.description: Detects outliers in the timeseries of Box login successes per Box user.
multiple_box_logins.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
multiple_box_logins.mitre_notes: This is too generic to map to a specific technique.
multiple_box_logins.name: Multiple Box Logins
multiple_box_logins.searchKeywords: dropbox google drive login log in logon log on sign

multiple_box_operations.description: Detects outliers in the timeseries of Box events per user.
multiple_box_operations.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
multiple_box_operations.mitre_notes: This is too generic to map to a specific technique.
multiple_box_operations.name: Multiple Box Operations

multiple_external_alarms.deprecated_not_used_anymore_datasource: DLP|IDS or IPS|Host-based IDS|Anti-Virus|Web Application Firewall
multiple_external_alarms.description: Detects outliers in the timeseries of external alarm per internal device.
multiple_external_alarms.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
multiple_external_alarms.mitre_notes: This is too generic to map to a specific technique. The alarms could be from various systems
multiple_external_alarms.name: Multiple External Alarms

multiple_logins.description: Detects outliers in the timeseries of workstation logins per user.
multiple_logins.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
multiple_logins.name: Multiple Logins
multiple_logins.searchKeywords: login log in logon log on sign

period_with_unusual_ad_activity_sequence.description: Correlates the rate of subtle changes in Active Directory behavior for each account. The correlation happens with: (a) each account's historic profile, and (b) with the activity of other accounts in the enterprise.
period_with_unusual_ad_activity_sequence.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
period_with_unusual_ad_activity_sequence.name: Period with Unusual Windows Security Event Sequences

potential_webshell_activity.description: Detects web shell activity by looking at accesses to internal Web servers (by external IPs only).
potential_webshell_activity.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
potential_webshell_activity.name: Potential Webshell Activity

scanning_activity.description: Identifies devices correlated to suspicious vertical and horizontal scanning patters.
scanning_activity.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
scanning_activity.name: Scanning Activity

suspicious_account_lockout.description: Looks for suspicious account lockouts that do not have any associations with password changes, password resets, password expiry within a specific time interval in and around the lockout period.
suspicious_account_lockout.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
suspicious_account_lockout.name: Suspicious Account Lockout

suspicious_box_usage.description: Looks for combinations of actions performed by a Box user or against a Box resource that are suspicious.
suspicious_box_usage.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
suspicious_box_usage.name: Suspicious Box Usage

suspicious_data_movement.description: Analyzes different types of data transfers per device and per account, both LAN and WAN, to identify unusual data movements. For example, the model monitors both inter firewall-zones LAN transfers and transfers to different countries and marks transfers that deviate from baseline.
suspicious_data_movement.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
suspicious_data_movement.name: Suspicious Data Movement

suspicious_domain_communication.description: Detects covert and malicious communication patterns in network traffic.
suspicious_domain_communication.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
suspicious_domain_communication.name: Suspicious Domain Communication

suspicious_domain_name.description: Detects algorithmically generated domain names using a machine learning model.
suspicious_domain_name.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
suspicious_domain_name.name: Suspicious Domain Name

suspicious_http_redirects.description: Detects sequences of HTTP requests within a short period of time that suggests infection has taken place.
suspicious_http_redirects.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
suspicious_http_redirects.name: Suspicious HTTP redirects

suspicious_ip_address_communication.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
suspicious_ip_address_communication.name: Suspicious IP Address Communication

suspicious_network_exploration.description: Detects users systematically increasing the number of devices that they access over time.
suspicious_network_exploration.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
suspicious_network_exploration.name: Suspicious Network Exploration

suspicious_powershell_activity.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
suspicious_powershell_activity.name: Suspicious Powershell Activity

suspicious_privilege_escalation.description: Detects suspicious privilege escalation by correlating login and privilege escalation events.
suspicious_privilege_escalation.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
suspicious_privilege_escalation.name: Suspicious Privilege Escalation
suspicious_privilege_escalation.searchKeywords: login log in logon log on sign

unusual_activity_time.description: Detects unusual activity time of day, or time of week by a user based on their normal access profile.
unusual_activity_time.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
unusual_activity_time.name: Unusual Activity Time

unusual_ad_event.description: Detects rare events in Microsoft Windows logs.
unusual_ad_event.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
unusual_ad_event.name: Unusual Windows Security Event

unusual_external_alarm.deprecated_not_used_anymore_datasource: DLP|IDS or IPS|Host-based IDS|Anti-Virus|Web Application Firewall
unusual_external_alarm.description: Detects external alarms (e.g., by firewalls) that have unusual characteristics.
unusual_external_alarm.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
unusual_external_alarm.mitre_notes: This is too generic to map to a specific technique. The alarms could be from various systems
unusual_external_alarm.name: Unusual External Alarm

unusual_geolocation_of_communication_des.description: Detects network events with rare destination IP geolocation.
unusual_geolocation_of_communication_des.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
unusual_geolocation_of_communication_des.name: Unusual Geolocation of Communication Destination

unusual_machine_access.description: Detects rare device accesses in Microsoft Windows logs.
unusual_machine_access.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
unusual_machine_access.name: Unusual Machine Access

unusual_network_activity.description: Detects events that have rare combination of port/application in firewall data.
unusual_network_activity.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
unusual_network_activity.name: Unusual Network Activity
unusual_network_activity.usecase: Advanced Threat Detection|Insider Threat|Security Monitoring|Insider Threat

unusual_time_of_badge_access.description: Detects badge access at unusual time.
unusual_time_of_badge_access.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
unusual_time_of_badge_access.name: Unusual Time of Badge Access

unusual_usb_activity.description: Generates anomalies for unusual transfers to/from USB devices. It also tracks the first time an account uses a USB and the first time a different type (e.g., vendor) of USB is used in the enterprise.
unusual_usb_activity.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
unusual_usb_activity.name: Unusual USB Activity

unusual_vpn_login_geolocation.description: Detects rare authentication locations in VPN data using geolocation.
unusual_vpn_login_geolocation.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
unusual_vpn_login_geolocation.name: Unusual VPN Login Geolocation
unusual_vpn_login_geolocation.searchKeywords: login log in logon log on sign

unusual_web_browser.description: Detects rare events for user agent string, device, and username in outbound HTTP data.
unusual_web_browser.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
unusual_web_browser.name: Unusual Web Browser

unusually_long_vpn_session.description: Detects unusually long VPN sessions, based on a user's baseline and their peer group.
unusually_long_vpn_session.help: Help not needed -- UBA Use Case
unusually_long_vpn_session.name: Unusually Long VPN Session
